rComments: Christine Hong is a brilliant thinker and a compassionate educator. I learned so much from her lectures. Be ready to think critically and deeply. Definitely talk to her in her office hour: she'll give you the best quality feedback.
Professor Hong did an excellent job. Would highly recommend.

Christine provides an open, interactive atmosphere to learn about racial topics in literature. She provides tons of helpful feedback and is a fair grader. She definitely has mad respect for her students and is just a genuine, kind human being. She's also hilarious and relatable. Would definitely recommend taking a class from her!

Christine is an AMAZING professor, she has opened my mind to so many new concepts and has taught me to think critically about the world. I really don't understand these other negative reviews because she is probably the best professor I've ever encountered. She is incredibly knowledgeable and really reaches out to her students. I highly recommend!
Christine's class was really exciting. I feel like she has to go kind of slow at the beginning to allow students less familiar with critical theory, but she is knowledgeable and funny.

Huh. I'm seeing a lot of negative reviews for Hong, and...  I don't really understand why. Honestly, she's one of the easiest profs I've ever had, and this was my SEMINAR. She gives really good feedback, and goes out of her way to help you do well. Seriously, ignore all the losers who say otherwise. She's great.

Christine is one of the few professors on this campus that genuinely cares about her students; she has provided me with more academic feedback than I have received in all four years  at UCSC. This class was cohesively productive, and I would recommend that everyone take a class with Christine. I think she's an absolute gem on this campus.
Extremely knowledgeable and excited about the subject she teaches.  Also possesses an admirable dedication to social justice, particularly issues pertaining to racial inequality.

I'm not quite sure why all these poor comments are posted.Christine is a wonderful lecturer and had her students incredibly engaged in class. She has wonderful perspectives on history's connection to literature and really wants her students to succeed. Perhaps my experience differs because I was in a smaller classroom environment, but she was great
In my three previous years at UCSC, hers was BY FAR the WORST class I've ever had. Horrible lectures, unclear about everything, and simply not cut out for being a college professor.

Awful teacher. Even ignoring the polarizing nature of her lectures, as you can probably see from the other reviews, she's genuinely bad. She lectures poorly, mostly reading directly from her notes, and has little control over her classes.   What's more, and there was a running competition between a large number of the students, she gets informati

Christine was very knowledgeable on the historical contexts $ you could easily tell just by attending lectures. People selected this class simply because the class title caught their attention. What do you expect from it though? Apparently people thought all they had to do was read comics. The final was very fair. Papers were graded a bit harsh tho

Okay, she is good-looking, let's be fair. And I thought the final was reasonable. But other than that, same as everyone else has said...lectures were indecipherable, I'd go to write something and stop half-way,  realizing I had no idea what she meant.  I felt constantly felt guilty for being American as well, so that was a bummer. Anyway, avoid.

A completely inept teacher, absolutely cannot handle a class of 200 kids. She is more distracting than the kids talking in class who she constantly berates. Did not critically analyze or even barely cover texts which cost plenty of money. Kind of seems nice but it's mostly just a cover for her holier-than-thou attitude. Was history instead of lit.

The worst teacher I've had in my life. She made NO effort to make the class engaging, and it was as if she purposely made it WAY harder than it needed to be just to make a point about the legitimacy of graphic novels as a form. It was a complete waste of my time. Essay prompts were paragraphs long and incomprehensible. Attendance was a chore.
She is terrible. Avoid at all costs.

I took the Graphic Novel class from Hong Winter quarter 2010, under the pretense I had signed up for a literature course... However, if anyone had told me that it was going to be a history class taught by an assistant professor whose lectures were absolutely POINTLESS and completely ignored the actual graphic novel texts...I might have reconsidered

Had her for graphic novels as well - how do you go wrong with that subject? Easily the worst lit professor I've ever had. It was kind of shocking how unprepared she was sometimes. She is a poor public speaker with soporific lectures. Her lectures often have no point and she really likes to use big words for no reason. TA Sophia was great though!

Christine is by far the worst literature professor I have ever had in my four years at UCSC.  The class was titled "The Graphic Novel", but instead of analyzing comix as a style of literature, she is teaching a ridiculous history course about "US exceptionalism". The reading list is excellent, but we rarely discuss the actual comics. Just plain bad
she is a bit hard to follow and she is very tough when she grades

Worst professor EVER.  Her lectures are just word vomit.  They are boring, strait reading from the notes, she incorporates ridiculous unnecessary words in lecture- I really can't figure out what it does for the class? Simplicity is best- however Hong would rather turn a sentence into an unclear 2 paragraphs.

This teacher is... new. Her lectures have absolutely nothing to do with the the promised subject matter (Graphic Novel Literature) and is all about the historical context of the works. She looks at her notes the entire time and sounds like she's reading from a thesaurus. I don't feel like I've learned anything this entire quarter.
